intro: Chloraster fissus, commonly known as the fissured chloraster, is a species of green algae belonging to the family Ulvaceae. It is characterized by its distinctive fissured thallus, which gives it a unique appearance compared to other members of its family. This algae typically grows in marine environments, particularly on rocky substrates in shallow coastal waters. Its structure consists of a flat, ribbon-like body with a central axis and lateral branches. Chloraster fissus plays a role in marine ecosystems by contributing to primary production and serving as a food source for various marine organisms.
